newsitem.title: GERMANY: More stray objects left in German patients-paper.
newsitem.headline: More stray objects left in German patients-paper.

text.p: More patients in German hospitals find stray objects have been left inside them after surgery than they did a decade ago, the weekly newspaper Die Zeit reported on Wednesday.

Peter Gausmann, an insurance risk consultant for hospitals in Germany, told Die Zeit that since 1995 about 280 alien objects had been left inside patients including swabs, sponges, wipes and even surgical scissors.

Gausmann said in the report released ahead of publication on Thursday this had become such a serious problem the number of law suits for such mistakes had tripled in the last decade, with more than 3,000 cases now compared to 1,000 in 1982.
Gausmann's firm advises hospitals how they can avoid accidents to reduce their insurance premiums.
He based his information on a study of 1,200 hospitals, more than half the country's 2,300 hospitals, and 150 clinics since 1995. He did not say why the phenomenon had grown.
